Description: Rim sherd of Chian Wild Goat Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed streaky black below; traces of bands in added red and white; exterior: very short billet pattern at rim above paired hook maeander pattern between pairs of lines; below from left, pair of narrow vertical lines with diagonal strokes (possibly part of pendant roundel); goose to right (head remaining); on the right, another pair of vertical lines with diagonal strokes (also possibly part of pendant roundel); dotted circle and short vertical strokes as filling ornament.
Producer name: Close to: Painter of the Aphrodite Bowl (according to Williams)
Attributed to: Group of the Aphrodite Bowl (according to Lemos)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd belongs to the same vase as Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.50.1894 and probably belongs to the same vase as GR.49.1894. Lemos describes the sherd as being in the style of the Würzburg chalices, but dated later than those chalices because she considers the style of the drawing to be debased and because of the elementary and isolated interior decoration. Williams prefers to see parallels with the Painter of the Aphrodite Bowl and suggests that the sherd is closely related to the bowl. He believes also that the painter for this vessel was responsible for British Museum 1888,0601.475.g, 1888,0601.475.d and 1924,1201.115.
Bibliographic references: CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 33, no. 18, pl. XVII)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 72, p. 241, no. 222, pl. 17)
Williams 2006a / The Chian Pottery from Naukratis (p. 132, note 28)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0379) (phase 2)
